generalfeedback.text:
\[@p@ = @v@^@rdm@\] So, using the rule for differentiation \[\frac{d}{dx}(x^n)=nx^{n-1},\]
\[\begin{array}{rcl}\displaystyle \frac{d}{d@v@}\left(@p@\right) &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm@@v@^{@rdm@-1} \\ &\displaystyle =&\displaystyle @rdm@@v@^{@rdm-1@}. \end{array}\]

truefeedback.text: You have lost a coefficient. The derivative of $x^n$ is $nx^{n-1}$, here $n=@rdm@$ but you do not appear to have a @rdm@ coefficient.

generalfeedback.text: The derivative of $cos(x)$ with respect to $x$ is $-sin(x)$, so \[\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] =@diff(p,v)@ .\]

truefeedback.text: The derivative of $\cos(mx)$ is $-m\sin(mx)$; you appear to have forgotten the factor $m$, in this case @rdm@.
The derivative of $\cos(x)$ is $-\sin(x)$; you appear to have used $\sin(x)$ as the derivative.
The derivative of $\cos(mx)$ is $-m\sin(mx)$ not $-m\sin(x)$.

generalfeedback.text: The derivative of $\sin(x)$ with respect to $x$ is $\cos(x)$, so \[\frac{d}{d@v@}\left[ @p@\right] =@rdm@@diff(p,v)/rdm@ .\]

The derivative of $\sin(x)$ is $\cos(x)$; you appear to have used $-\cos(x)$ as the derivative.
The derivative of $\sin(mx)$ is $m\cos(mx)$ not $m\cos(x)$.
